Who is Chad Fraser?

I've always struggled with this question before. It's not that I don't know who I am, but it's very hard for anyone to recite interesting facts about themselves on the spot. It's even more difficult to really zero in on what it is that makes us 'ourselves', and what's just filler in our identity. What sets us apart from everyone else? What is fundamental to who we are? What's just background noise, and what's really important in our lives?

I've thought long and hard about this question now, and I have finally come up with six things that I think strike the core of the question "Who is Chad Fraser?".

Chad Fraser is...
a programmer.

Chad Fraser is...
a proud McGill graduate.

After graduating high school, I was fortunate enough to be accepted into the beautiful and prestigious McGill University in Montreal, Quebec. Some of the best friendships I've ever had were made at McGill, and attending this university offered me countless events and adventures that I could never have experienced otherwise. Being immersed in a culture as unique and fascinating as Montreal's is an opportunity I will never regret having taken. It took a lot of hard work and struggle to graduate from McGill University, but it is one of my proudest accomplishments, and one I will never forget.

Chad Fraser is...
improvisational.

I pride myself on my professional and hard-working attitude, but that doesn't mean that I don't know how to cut back and have fun! I was a member of the McGill University improv team during my time studying there. Unfortunately, scheduling conflicts with other clubs meant that I had to reluctantly leave the team only a couple years in. Even so, there was nothing that could ever begin compare to the feeling of crafting a spontaneous story with my teammates!

There's no better way to pump up a team and bring some energy into a room than with improv exercises and games. It's one of the few arts where the entire scene falling apart around you can be just as much fun as everything going perfectly to plan, and the spirit and soul of improv will always be a part of my core identity.

Chad Fraser is...
a board game fanatic!

Ever since I was a kid, I have loved playing board games with my friends! Of course, none of my high-school-aged friends had a very expansive games catalog: When we played, it would often be Settlers of Catan, Risk, Clue, or else a trading card game.

But early into my first year at McGill University, I joined its small student-run board games club. This opened my eyes to how truly diverse and exciting the world of board gaming was. They had nearly a hundred games at the club, and every now and then a member would bring in a new one to share with everybody there. It was an amazing experience to be able to explore so many games!

I volunteered to take the position of the board game club's secretary the first week that I joined the club. Even though there were fewer than ten regular members when I first joined, we had several dozen regular members by the time I graduated years later, and I will forever be grateful that I had the opportunity to play so many different kinds of games with all of them.

Some of my favorite games include:

  • Betrayal at House on the Hill
  • Arkham Horror
  • Advanced Civilization
  • Race for the Galaxy
  • Puerto Rico
  • 7 Wonders

Chad Fraser is...
an avid mahjong* player.

I had been intrigued and fascinated by the concept of mahjong ever since I came across it in some of the comics I had read as a teenager. As soon as I learned that the university I attended had a student-run mahjong club, I jumped at the chance to join. It is by far one of my favorite games, and I still spend a lot of my free time playing online Japanese-style mahjong (though I'm admittedly not very good at it!). I wrote a blog dedicated to mahjong during my time as the university mahjong club's president, and have countless fond memories of playing the game with my friends there.

I own three mahjong sets in total (though one is missing a few tiles, unfortunately, and one has transparent tiles for a gimmicky gameplay variation), and love teaching the game to new players as much as I love playing it myself!

One of my dreams is to find another group of eager and fun friends to play this beautiful game with in-person, on a regular basis once more.


* The four-player mahjong game, not the solitaire game.

Chad Fraser is...
a teacher.

I am licensed and qualified to teach in two Canadian provinces: Both in Alberta, where I grew up, and Quebec, where I studied in post-secondary schooling. Ever since I was young, I had been fascinated with the subject of math, and what an exciting field it was. There was so many interesting things you could do with it, and as a teenager, I loved stumbling across fun (yet simple enough for me to understand!) quirks of math like the Banach-Tarski paradox, or Cantor's diagonalization proof. It was honestly fun to learn about all of these concepts!

But even as a kid, it was clear to me that my classmates weren't nearly as enamored with it as I was. Almost all of my friends struggled to pick up on the material that came to me so easily. At first I started just helping my friends understand how to complete the assigned worksheets during class, but the more I worked at helping them learn, the more I realized how enjoyable doing so was. It was great seeing how excited they got when something clicked in their minds! Before too long, I was volunteering at the high school's tutoring center and making some study guides for my friends before finals.

This was when I first resolved to study education in university. The more I taught my friends and tutored other students, the more I realized that a lot of these students were bright kids that just weren't being taught in an effective way that would let them really grasp the material. I wanted to help design and present methods of learning math that students could relate to and understand on a deeper level.

Though some of my passions may have changed over the years, my desire to help others find new understandings is inherent to who I am.
